update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

~~b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.~~

~~Failing tests:~~

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.
update.title: DART LCP Solver

content.html: Oops. Fixed in 478d5d3.

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

~~b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.~~

~~Failing tests:~~

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.
update.title: DART LCP Solver

content.raw: Three tests are failing which appear decidedly unrelated to this pull request. I'm not sure what the appropriate procedure is for dealing with that kind of situation. Regardless of those (seemingly unrelated) test failures, I believe this PR is good.

content.raw:
A test file:
~~~
<?xml version='1.0'?>
<sdf version='1.5'>
  <world name="default">

    <physics type="dart">
      <dart>
        <solver>
          <solver_type>pgs</solver_type>
        </solver>
      </dart>
    </physics>

    <include>
      <uri>model://ground_plane</uri>
    </include>

    <include>
      <uri>model://sun</uri>
    </include>

    <model name='box0'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0 0.6 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name='link_0'>
        <pose frame=''>0 0.4 0 0.1 0 0</pose>
        <visual name='visual'>
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>0.1 0.2 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
        <collision name='collision'>
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>0.1 0.2 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
      </link>
      <joint name='join_0' type='revolute'>
        <parent>world</parent>
        <child>link_0</child>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 -0.4 0 0 0</pose>
        <axis>
          <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>

    <model name='box1'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0 0.6 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name='link_1'>
        <pose frame=''>0 -0.4 0 -0.1 0 0</pose>
        <visual name='visual'>
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>0.1 0.2 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </visual>
        <collision name='collision'>
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>0.1 0.2 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
      </link>
      <joint name='joint_1' type='revolute'>
        <parent>world</parent>
        <child>link_1</child>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 -0.4 0 0 0</pose>
        <axis>
          <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
        </axis>
      </joint>
    </model>

  </world>
</sdf>
~~~

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

~~b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.~~

~~Failing tests:~~

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.
update.title: DART LCP Solver

content.raw: Yes, I believe pull request #2758 addresses the segfault. I also circumvented the issue in [6a4c6f9](https://bitbucket.org/pchorak/gazebo/commits/6a4c6f9) by allowing the solver to be specified in the sdf. Oddly, the segfault did not occur when using the dantzig solver, so the tests should pass in the PR's current state as well.
content.html: Yes, I believe pull request #2758 addresses the segfault. I also circumvented the issue in 6a4c6f9 by allowing the solver to be specified in the sdf. Oddly, the segfault did not occur when using the dantzig solver, so the tests should pass in the PR's current state as well.

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

~~b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.~~

~~Failing tests:~~

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

~~b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.

Failing tests:

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).~~

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.
update.title: DART LCP Solver

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.

Failing tests:

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.
update.title: DART LCP Solver

content.raw:
good point, we can be more careful about that. before calling `GetElement`, we should check if it `HasElement`, and if not, return a default value, probably `"dantzig"`. we should document the default value in the `GetElement` doxygen

also, we should add this parameter to the `DARTPhysics::[GS]etParam` functions. see pull request #2512 and [ODEPhysics::SetParam](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/40c062da7dcc0ca6977a420cc7e66cd7a4f9f9eb/gazebo/physics/ode/ODEPhysics.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#ODEPhysics.cc-1410)
content.html:
good point, we can be more careful about that. before calling GetElement, we should check if it HasElement, and if not, return a default value, probably "dantzig". we should document the default value in the GetElement doxygen

also, we should add this parameter to the DARTPhysics::[GS]etParam functions. see pull request #2512 and ODEPhysics::SetParam

content.raw: Ah, yes. Is there a way around that?
content.html: Ah, yes. Is there a way around that?

content.raw: it won't work without a new sdformat release
content.html: it won't work without a new sdformat release

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.

Failing tests:

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.
update.title: DART LCP Solver

content.raw: Agreed. `[GS]etSolverType` makes more sense. I had copied the name from ODE, which uses the solver differently.
content.html: Agreed. [GS]etSolverType makes more sense. I had copied the name from ODE, which uses the solver differently.

content.raw: Do these need to be virtual? Also, `[GS]etSolverType` sounds more precise to me than `[GS]etStepType`
content.html: Do these need to be virtual? Also, [GS]etSolverType sounds more precise to me than [GS]etStepType

content.raw: I styled 6a4c6f9 after the ODE solver (i.e. `<solver><type></type></solver>`, `SetStepType`, etc.). However, the solvers do not play the same role, so it may be better to use different names. What do you think?
content.html: I styled 6a4c6f9 after the ODE solver (i.e. <solver><type></type></solver>, SetStepType, etc.). However, the solvers do not play the same role, so it may be better to use different names. What do you think?

update.description:
By default DART uses ODE's Dantzig LCP solver to handle constraints. However, the solver returns nan values in some situations ([DART issue #892](https://github.com/dartsim/dart/issues/892)). Kinematic loops with revolute joints are one of the problematic situations.

b3cc07d has DART use a Projected Gauss-Seidel (PGS) solver instead. Doing so makes it possible to simulate kinematic loops with revolute joints among other things. There is some precedence for choosing the PGS solver since , when using ODE, Gazebo [defaults](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/654ab4c930e1abe28208df47d4a49d8cf7515e08/sdf/1.6/physics.sdf?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#physics.sdf-165) to [ its PGS solver](http://wiki.ros.org/physics_ode/ODE#SOR_PGS_LCP). However, switching to DART's PGS solver causes some tests to fail.

Failing tests:

INTEGRATION_joint_force_torque

* In `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce` and `GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForceReset` the base jitters a little bit, which causes some of the elements of the joint wrench that should be `0.0` to deviate (e.g. wrench_01.body1Force.Y()). The test failure can be eliminated by adding a fixed joint between the world and the first link.

INTEGRATION_physics

* In the `SpawnDrop` test, one of the objects is sliding just a little bit too much after the drop.
~~~
/home/osrf/default/test/integration/physics.cc:285: Failure
The difference between vel1.Y() and 0 is 0.021639389744573603, which exceeds 1e-2, where
vel1.Y() evaluates to 0.021639389744573603,
0 evaluates to 0, and
1e-2 evaluates to 0.01.
~~~

INTEGRATION_factory

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

Update: 6a4c6f9 in conjunction with [PR #369](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/369) makes the DART LCP solver a parameter that can be set as suggested by @scpeters. So, the tests should now pass.

* In the `Box` test (but not the `Sphere` test), the program has  a segmentation fault while cleaning up. It may have to do with the comment [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/801eaafce237e0858670e9354ff9113fe2527f32/gazebo/physics/dart/DARTModel.cc?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#DARTModel.cc-297).

content.raw: Good idea. That should be a quick fix for the failing tests.
content.html: Good idea. That should be a quick fix for the failing tests.

content.raw: I can advise on this more thoroughly when I return

content.raw: It might be best to make the LCP solver a physics parameter that can be set for each world file since they seem to do better in different situations.
content.html: It might be best to make the LCP solver a physics parameter that can be set for each world file since they seem to do better in different situations.
